questions.text: A researcher is analyzing a segment of double-stranded DNA as part of an experiment to understand gene expression in a particular type of cancer. The researcher finds that in this DNA segment, thymine makes up 28% of the nucleotides. Based on this information, what is the percentage of guanine in this DNA segment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 22%

 

Option D.

             

Based on Chargaffâ€™s rule:

 

Purines = Pyrimidine; No. of Adenine = No. of Thymine

 

So, Adenine + Thymine = 28 + 28 = 56%

 

Guanine + Cytosine = 44%

 

No. of Guanine = No. of Cytosine

 

So, the amount of Guanine = 44/2 = 22%

 

Explanations:

 

Option A. 26%: False

 

Option B. 44%: Guanine + Cytosine = 44% (Guanine alone =22%)

 

Option C. 56%: Adenine + Thymine = 28 + 28 = 56%

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chargaff's rules emphasize the importance of recognizing that in double-stranded DNA, the percentages of adenine and thymine are equal, as are the percentages of cytosine and guanine.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 360; Lippincott 7/e: P 397.

questions.text: In an experiment aimed at understanding DNA replication, a piece of radio-labeled DNA is allowed to undergo two rounds of replication within a non-radioactive medium. This setup is designed to track the distribution of the original radioactive material across the generations of DNA. Based on the known mechanism of semiconservative replication, what would be the expected outcome regarding the radioactivity of the DNA strands after two replication cycles?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Half of the DNA will have no radioactivity

 

Explanation:

 

DNA replication follows a semiconservative model, meaning that each daughter DNA molecule retains one original (parental) strand and synthesizes one new strand.

  • After the first round of replication, each of the two daughter DNA molecules contains one radioactive parental strand and one new non-radioactive strand. So, all DNA molecules are partially radioactive.

 

 

  • After the second round of replication, each of these hybrid molecules produces:
    • One hybrid DNA (still containing one radioactive strand)
    • One entirely new DNA molecule (both strands non-radioactive)

 

So now there are four DNA molecules total:

  • Two are hybrid (radioactive + non-radioactive)
  • Two are completely non-radioactive

 

Therefore, half of the DNA molecules (2 out of 4) are non-radioactive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: All strands will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. Only the original strands are radioactive, and they are passed on to only half of the DNA molecules after two replications.

 

Option B: No strands will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. The original radioactive strands still exist in two of the four DNA molecules.

 

Option D: Three-fourth of the DNA will have radioactivity â€” Incorrect. Only two out of four DNA molecules (i.e., 50%) retain radioactive material, not 75%.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the implications of semiconservative DNA replication: in each new round, half of the DNA molecules retain part of the original strand. 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 381-387.

questions.text: Which of the following cell types do not have the enzyme telomerase that protects the length of telomeres at the chromosomal ends?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Somatic

 

Explanation:

 

Telomerase is an enzyme that adds repetitive nucleotide sequences to the ends of chromosomes (telomeres), thereby preventing their progressive shortening during DNA replication. This is especially important in cells that divide frequently or require long-term proliferative potential.

 

Somatic cells, which constitute the majority of cells in the body (like skin, muscle, and liver cells), lack significant telomerase activity. As a result, with each cell division, telomeres become progressively shorter. Eventually, this leads to cellular senescence or programmed cell death (apoptosis), which is a natural part of aging.

 

In contrast:

  • Germinal (germ) cells have active telomerase to ensure genomic stability is passed on to offspring.
  • Tumor cells often reactivate telomerase, which enables them to escape normal cellular aging and divide indefinitely â€” a key feature of cancer.
  • Hemopoietic stem cells (in bone marrow) also express telomerase to maintain their replicative capacity and continually replenish blood cells.

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that somatic cells typically lack telomerase, which causes telomere shortening over time and contributes to the natural aging process and cellular lifespan limitation. This contrasts with cell types like germinal, stem, and cancer cells, where telomerase activity supports sustained proliferation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 374.

questions.text: When discussing the differences between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100 proteins, which are both derived from the same ApoB gene but expressed differently in the intestine and liver, respectively, it's crucial to understand the molecular mechanism responsible for their diversity. These proteins are vital for lipid metabolism, with Apo-B48 being involved in chylomicron formation and Apo-B100 in VLDL and LDL. What process leads to the production of these distinct proteins from the same mRNA transcript?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deamination of Cytidine to Uridine

 

Option C:

 

mRNA editing

 

 

  • In the liver, the single apo-B gene is transcribed into an mRNA which leads to the synthesis of a 100-kDa protein, apo-B100.

  • In the intestine, the same gene directs the synthesis of the primary transcript â†’cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site.

  • Rather than encoding glutamine, this codon acts as a termination signal and a 48-kDa protein (apoB48) is the result.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. RNA splicing: While RNA splicing is a common mechanism to generate protein diversity by removing introns from the pre-mRNA, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100. These proteins result from the same gene and mRNA transcript but differ due to a specific editing event.

 

Option B. Allelic exclusion: This process, where only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other is silenced, is not related to the production of Apo-B48 and Apo-B100. These proteins come from the same mRNA transcript and gene but are differentially processed in different tissues.

 

Option D. Upstream repression: This refers to a regulatory mechanism where gene expression is inhibited by factors binding to regions upstream of the gene. This mechanism does not explain the production of two different proteins from the same mRNA transcript as seen with Apo-B48 and Apo-B100.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The difference between Apo-B48 and Apo-B100 arises from the editing of the ApoB mRNA through the deamination of a specific cytidine to uridine in the intestinal cells. This conversion creates a stop codon in the mRNA, leading to the production of the shorter Apo-B48 protein in the intestine. In contrast, the liver cells do not perform this editing, resulting in the full-length Apo-B100 protein.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 393

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl in a rural clinic near Pune presents with chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, and a sore throat. On examination, the physician observes a persistent greyish-white colored membrane over the tonsils. The girl's vaccination card indicates that she has not been immunized against diphtheria. Considering the pathophysiology of diphtheria toxin, which of the following is the reason it is lethal in unimmunized cases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inactivates an elongation factor required for translocation in protein synthesis

 

Option A.

 

  • Diphtheria toxin has two subunits â€“ A and B. The B subunit binds to a cell surface receptor, thereby facilitating the entry of the A subunit into the cell.

 

  • The A subunit then catalyzes the ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF2) â†’ thus inhibiting it from participating in the translocation process of protein synthesis â†’ hence, stops protein synthesis.

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin targets and inactivates elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is essential for the translocation step of protein synthesis on ribosomes. This inactivation prevents the movement of the ribosome along the mRNA, thus halting protein synthesis, which can lead to cell death.

questions.text: A research team studying bacterial genetics exposes a culture to a chemical mutagen. The bacteria, which typically require minimal nutrition, are then plated on a nutrient-rich medium. Individual colonies that form are subsequently tested for their ability to grow on a minimal medium. Those failing to thrive are identified as mutants, and genomic sequencing reveals a deletion of a two-nucleotide segment in their DNA. What type of mutation does this deletion most likely produce?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Frameshift mutation  

 

Option A:

 

  • Frameshift mutation: It causes deletion of nucleotides which are not multiples of 3 and the genetic code will be read differently from that or till another alteration in the DNA restores the original reading frame (e.g., addition of two base pairs or deletion of another base pair).

  • This mutation often results in a truncated protein.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Conservative mutation (Incorrect): It is a Missense mutation which leads to the substitution of a given amino acid with a chemically similar amino acid.

 

Option C. Missense mutation (Incorrect): It leads to the replacement of a given amino acid with a different amino acid.

 

Option D. Nonsense mutation (Incorrect): It introduces a stop codon instead of a codon specific for an amino acid, causing premature chain termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deletion of a two-nucleotide segment within a gene's coding region typically results in a frameshift mutation. Because the genetic code is read in triplets (codons), removing two nucleotides alters the reading frame downstream of the mutation, likely changing every subsequent amino acid in the protein product. This shift can lead to a nonfunctional protein due to extensive missense mutations and the potential introduction of a premature stop codon (nonsense mutation).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who has inherited one mutant allele of the BRCA1 gene has a 60% risk of developing breast cancer by age 50. The BRCA1 gene encodes a protein that plays a crucial role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which DNA repair process is most likely impaired by a deficiency in BRCA1 protein function?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Homologous recombination

 

Option D:

 

  • BRCA1 plays an important role in the repair of double-strand breaks.

  • Since homologous recombination requires a cleavage of both strands of a DNA molecule â†’ deficiency of this gene/protein would affect the event of homologous recombination.

 

Explanation:

Option B. Removal of RNA primers: RNA primers are removed during DNA replication, a process unrelated to the repair function of BRCA1.

 

Option C. Removal of carcinogen adducts: Like thymine dimers, carcinogen adducts are typically addressed by nucleotide excision repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 protein is fundamentally involved in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks primarily through homologous recombination, a critical process during cell division that ensures the accurate repair of DNA to prevent mutations that could lead to cancer. When BRCA1 function is compromised, the efficiency of homologous recombination repair is significantly reduced, which increases the risk of genomic instability and contributes to cancer predisposition, particularly breast and ovarian cancers.

Based on this information, which statement best describes these genes?

questions.text: Which of the following modifications is primarily responsible for the inactivation of genes found within CpG islands?

Option B. Acetylation: Acetylation, particularly of histone proteins, is generally associated with the activation of gene expression by making chromatin more accessible to transcriptional machinery, not inactivation.

 

Educational Objective:

  • CpG islands are the most common sites of methylation-demethylation.

  • Thus, they play an important role in regulation of gene expression

questions.text: A research team is studying bacterial resistance mechanisms against viral phage infections and focuses on the CRISPR system. In discussing its features, which of the following statements about CRISPR is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Provides no protection to the bacterium from phage infection  

 

Option D:

 

The false statement regarding CRISPR is that it "Offers no bacterial protection against phage" (d). CRISPR, along with associated Cas (CRISPR-associated) proteins, forms an adaptive immune system in bacteria and archaea, providing protection against invading genetic elements like phages by recognizing and cleaving their DNA, thereby preventing infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Named for its sequence characteristics: True. The name CRISPR reflects the unique organization of short, partially palindromic repeated DNA sequences found in the genomes of bacteria and archaea.

 

Option B: Works in conjunction with Cas nuclease: True. The CRISPR system functions with Cas proteins, particularly the Cas nuclease, to identify and cut foreign DNA based on RNA sequences derived from previous invasions.

 

Option C: Can cleave invading phage DNA: True. The CRISPR-Cas system can specifically target and cleave DNA from invading phages, guided by RNA molecules that match the phage DNA sequences, providing a form of acquired immunity.


Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR/CAS system:

 

  • A prokaryotic immune system conferring resistance to external genes from bacteriophage.

  • This system provides a bacterial version of acquired immunity.

  • CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) spacer derived RNA combines with the Cas nuclease to target and specifically cleave the DNA of invading phage, there by inactivating these invading genomes and protecting the bacterium from productive phage infection and lysis.

  • These contain sequences that are repeated in tandem for a variable number of times and its length is unique for everyone.

  • As it is a DNA fragment being analyzed, Southern blot is the best technique to separate and detect these regions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DNA sequencing: Though it can detect DNA similarities but It is expensive and time-consuming for forensic analysis. It can be used for a confirmatory analysis.

 

Option B. Northern blot: It is used to separate and detect RNA.

 

Option D. Western blot: It is used for detection of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Southern blot is the best technique for the initial analysis in this context, as it is used for DNA analysis, specifically to detect certain sequences within a DNA sample by using restriction enzymes and a DNA probe. This method is well-suited for VNTR analysis, which is a type of polymorphism that can be highly variable among individuals and is useful for forensic DNA typing.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 456-457.

questions.text: A research team is examining the regulation of fetal hemoglobin expression and the gene product involved in its down regulation. They have primary tissue cultures from fetal, neonatal, and adult liver and bone marrow, along with a DNA probe for the gene of interest. To determine the gene's expression levels in these tissue culture samples, which method is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Northern blot.

 

Option B:

 

  • In a Northern blot â†’ all the mRNA from a cell type is electrophoresed on a gel â†’ blotted onto the nitrocellulose â†’ the DNA probe is applied and hybridized â†’ excess is washed off â†’ final resultant blot is autoradiographed. 

  • Bands on the autoradiograph film indicate the mRNAs contains sequences complementary to the probe â†’ Shows the gene on the probe has been expressed in the mRNA of that cell. 

  • This is the best technique for determining whether a gene is expressed in a particular cell type.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: DNA sequencing and Option D: Southern blot: These techniques examine the DNA of the cell and the DNA of all the cells involved is identical.

 

Option C: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): It is used to amplify DNA and cannot determine which tissue culture has expressed the gene being studied. It also amplifies the DNA probe which is necessary for Northern blotting. However, in this case, the DNA probe was supplied in adequate amounts â†’ therefore PCR is not recommended.

 

Educational objective:

 

Northern blotting is the correct method for determining the expression of a specific gene. It measures mRNA levels, which correlate directly with gene expression. This technique involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labelled probe specific to the mRNA of interest.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 456-457.

questions.text: A researcher is discussing the application of RNA interference (RNAi) technology in gene expression studies during a molecular biology conference. RNAi primarily results in which of the following effects on gene expression?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knock down.

 

Option A:

 

  • Gene Knock down: siRNA or miRNA induced gene silencing is called RNA interference or RNAi.

  • RNA interference (RNAi) is a mechanism of gene silencing through decreased expression of mRNA, either by increased degradation or repression of translation.

  • It is mediated by short (~22 bp), noncoding RNAs called microRNAs (miRNAs)

  • It plays a key role in cell proliferation, differentiation and apoptosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Gene Knock up: Transcription of gene is increased using transcription factors.

 

Option C: Gene Knock in: Mutated endogenous gene is replaced by normal transgene by homologous recombination in embryonic stem cell.

 

Option D: Gene Knock out: Endogenous gene is replaced by mutated transgene by homologous recombination in embryonic stem cell.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression, typically by causing the destruction of specific mRNA molecules. The primary effect of RNAi on gene expression is a "knock down," where the expression of the targeted gene is reduced but not completely eliminated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 447.

questions.text: A research team is utilizing various laboratory techniques to quantify the concentration of DNA samples extracted from patient biopsies. They are considering the most appropriate method that would provide accurate, rapid, and non-destructive analysis. Which of the following instruments is best suited for the quantitative analysis of DNA in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) UV spectrometer

 

Explanation:

 

A UV spectrometer (or spectrophotometer) is the standard and most widely used instrument for the rapid, non-destructive quantification of DNA.

 

DNA strongly absorbs ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 260 nm due to its nucleotide bases. Using Beer-Lambertâ€™s law, the absorbance at this wavelength can be directly related to the DNA concentration:

 

This method is:

  • Fast
  • Non-destructive
  • Accurate for pure DNA samples.

 

In contrast to other methods, it does not require dyes, gels, or amplification, making it ideal for direct concentration measurement.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Gel electrophoresis:
    Useful for qualitative analysis (e.g., DNA size, integrity) but not as accurate for quantification. It is also destructive, and staining agents like ethidium bromide are needed.
  • Option C) Light microscope: Incorrect.
    A light microscope is used to visualize cells or large cell structures, not molecules like DNA, and cannot provide concentration data.
  • Option D) PCR machine: Incorrect.
    PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is designed to amplify specific DNA sequences, not for direct DNA quantification. Quantitative PCR (qPCR) can estimate copy numbers of specific targets, but not general DNA concentration before the amplification process.

 

Educational Objective (Polished):


DNA can be accurately quantified using UV spectrophotometry at 260 nm, exploiting the strong absorbance of nucleic acid bases. This method is non-destructive, fast, and reliable, and is widely used before downstream applications like PCR, cloning, or sequencing.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 744.

questions.text: Following a positive ELISA screening test for HIV, a patient undergoes a confirmatory Western blot test. For this assay, which component is specifically separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis before being transferred to a membrane for detection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HIV proteins

 

Option D:

 

The HIV tests are looking for the presence of antibodies in the patients sera against HIV proteins. So, in the confirming western blot, HIV proteins are separated by size on a polyacrylamide gel, the proteins transferred to filter, and the filter paper treated with sera sample. If the sera contains antibodies to HIV proteins, they will bind to the proteins on the filter paper and the presence of antibodies on the filter paper is then detected using secondary antibodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Patient sera and Option B: Patient plasma: While these are used in the test, they are not separated by the gel. Instead, antibodies in the sera or plasma react with the HIV proteins on the membrane.

 

Option C: HIV RNA: This would not be used in a Western blot, which is a protein-detection method. HIV RNA could be detected using techniques like RT-PCR, not Western blot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a Western blot test for HIV, the components that are separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane for detection are HIV proteins. These proteins are detected by their reaction with antibodies in the patient's serum, confirming the presence of an HIV infection.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 736.

questions.text: Given the DNA template shown, with regions A, B, C, and D, which pair of primers should be used to effectively amplify this region through PCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B and C

 

Option A:

 

  • For a PCR experiment, primers are important that will allow DNA synthesis to occur across the region of DNA to be amplified.

  • As DNA polymerase always synthesizes DNA in the 5â€™ to 3â€™ direction, the 3â€™ ends of the primers must face each other and bracket the region of DNA to be amplified.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B, Option C, Option D: Primers Option A and Option D will only allow DNA synthesis away in the opposite direction from the region of interest, due to their orientation on the DNA template strand.

When designing primers for PCR amplification, it is important to select primer pairs that are complementary to the 3' ends of opposite strands of the target DNA region. This ensures that the DNA polymerase can successfully amplify the entire region between the primers.

questions.text: A teenage boy, self-conscious about his weight, decides to follow a fat-free diet in hopes of improving his physique. After adhering to this dietary regimen for several weeks, he visits a nutritionist for a consultation. Concerned about potential nutritional deficiencies and their impact on lipid metabolism, the nutritionist reviews the boy's diet and decides to assess his body's ability to synthesize various essential lipids that might be affected by his restrictive diet:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandins

 

Option B:

 

Prostaglandins are synthesized from essential fatty acids, such as arachidonic acid, which are typically obtained from dietary fats. A fat-free diet could lead to a deficiency in essential fatty acids, impacting the body's ability to synthesize prostaglandins. Prostaglandins play various roles in the body, including inflammation, pain modulation, and regulation of blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cholesterol: The body can synthesize cholesterol endogenously, primarily in the liver, and its synthesis is less likely to be directly affected by a fat-free diet.

 

Option C: Glycolipids: Glycolipids are composed of a carbohydrate and a lipid. While dietary fats influence lipid components, the body can also synthesize these from other sources.

 

Option D: Phospholipids: Phospholipids can be synthesized endogenously from glycerol, fatty acids, and phosphate. The body can adapt to variations in dietary fat intake to maintain phospholipid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prostaglandins are synthesized from arachidonic acid.

  • Arachidonic acid is synthesized from linoleic acid, which is an essential fatty acid supplied from dietary lipids in adequate amounts.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 213-215, 238-240.
